div.head: Astronomical Education
div.p: Between 1826 and 1828, astronomy featured persistently in Ruskin's poetry and prose, from the mention of the British child's beginner's constellation, Charles's Wain, in the 1826/27 poem, “Glen of Glenfarg” [“Glen of Glenfarg thy beauteous rill”]; to the catalogue of constellation names from all around the celestial globe, “The Constellations”; to Lucy's task of memorizing constellations and their respective numbers of stars in “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol III” to the Miltonic hymn of praise in the New Year's poem for January 1828, “The Sun”. Ruskin composed these works in context of rising popular education in astronomy for adults and children in the first three decades of the early nineteenth century in Britain. He was engaged primarily by the poetic sublimity of the subject, although these works contain hints that he gained at least basic conceptual understanding of the solar system.

div.head: Star Atlases
div.p: In “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol III”, Ruskin's "Harry" "took one of his lesson books and made Lucy learn the following constellations with the number of stars" (chap. 1); and there follow at intervals lists of constellation names with their respective total counts of stars comprised within each formation. The "lesson book" that sourced Ruskin's star numbers has so far eluded detection, since his totals fail to match the statistics supplied in British astronomy texts commonly available in the 1820s. Changes of course occurred over time in the observable number of stars counted within the constellation boundaries, and the constellations themselves changed as new ones were added and others consigned to obsolescence. Ruskin may also have based his counts on some method of his own devising, such as numbering only stars of a certain magnitude. In any case, this kind of information was found in a star atlas.

Of star atlases that might have been available to Ruskin in the 1820s, a logical choice would have been the chief modern British accomplishment in this field, A Celestial Atlas Comprising a Systematic Display of the Heavens in a Series of Thirty Maps Illustrated by Scientific Descriptions of Their Contents, and Accompanied by Catalogues of the Stars and Astronomical Exercises by Alexander Jamieson (1782–1850). Published in two editions in 1822, followed by a reprint circa 1823–24, the Celestial Atlas was an advanced and up‐to‐date work by a Scottish‐ and English‐educated schoolmaster, which included lessons and exercises designed for “beginners, rather than . . . adepts in the science”, and which was “composed in a popular language, without any regard to the learned phraseology of Astronomers” (preface, ii). Embellished with plates elegantly rendering the mythical figures representing the constellations, the Celestial Atlas provided a British public with a star atlas that could compete with the French and German atlases then in common use. (Jamiesonʼs atlas boasted a dedication to the king, George IV. For its publication history and biographical information on Jamieson, see Ridpath, “Celestial Atlas by Alexander Jamieson”).

Notwithstanding Jamieson's target audience of “beginners, rather than . . . adepts”, any star atlas would have posed a daunting text for Ruskin at ages seven to nine. In 1835, when he was sixteen, the Ruskins may have acquired a different textbook by Jamieson, A Grammar of Logic and Intellectual Philosophy on Didactic Principles (1819). (Dearden identifies this text predicated on an entry, “Jamieson 6/6”, for 14 May 1835 in John James Ruskinʼs Account Book [39v], an entry that, as Van Akin Burd admits, could apply, not just to various works by Alexander Jamieson but also to works by the geologist Robert Jamieson [1774–1854]. See Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 183 [no. 1405]; and Ruskin Family Letters, ed. Burd, 300–301 n. 12. Identification of this item recorded in John Jamesʼs accounts as a textbook by Alexander Jamieson is unclear, therefore, although Dearden correlates this item with a gift to the Working Menʼs College in 1858.)

Regardless of whether Ruskin was exposed directly to Jamieson's Celestial Atlas, the publication influenced other, more introductory-level texts that he might have used.
In 1828, if they had acquired Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas, its exercises would surely have demanded too much of Ruskinʼs abilities. As remarked previously, the random order in which he names constellations in his poem suggests that he failed to master even the most basic astronomical concepts, as presented in Mrs. Sherwoodʼs elementary primer. Nonetheless, the atlas would have appealed not only in its visual depictions and prose summaries of myths; it would also have bolstered Ruskinʼs pride in British achievements in astronomical discovery and science. A consistent theme in Ruskinʼs poem is his observance of constellations with British associations, such as Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), Robur Caroli (Charlesʼs Oak), and Telescopium Herschelii (Herschellʼs Telescope).

Mrs. Sherwood advises: “A teacher, when hearing the class, should use globes, or plates, such as may be found in most elementary books of astronomy, to assist the children in understanding what they learn” (Introduction to Astronomy, vii). Plates and globes depicted the mythical figures for which the constellations were named; and plates were found in star atlases, which among other information related the stories associated with the stars and constellations, such as the myth of the Milky Way (Via Lactea) that Ruskin uses to frame his conclusion to the second fair copy (MS III): “the ancients thought” it “the road / Which all their best and bravest trod / Unto great Jupiters blest abode”.

Still, a confirmed source of Ruskinʼs exposure to the mythology of the constellations remains elusive, as does a measure of his knowledge of those stories. The contextual glosses identify the constellations named in Ruskinʼs poem and summarize their stories, drawing on two sources published in the 1820s: Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas and an American work (partly dependent on Jamiesonʼs), Astronomical Recreations (1824) by Jacob Green (1790‐1841). How familiar this information would have been to Ruskin himself in this period is unknown.
